chunks.original_latin:
HAYMO HALBERSTATENSIS EPISCOPUS
IN MALACHIAM PROPHETAM.
chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
On the Prophet Malachi  
<break time="500ms"/>
by Haymo Bishop of Halberstadt
<break time="2s"/>
</speak>

In Malachiam Prohetam. The Hebrews believe that Malachi, the last of the twelve prophets, was Ezra, who was both a prophet and a priest. He prophesied at the same time as Haggai and Zechariah, which is why no specific time is given in the title. His name means "angel of the Lord" or "my angel," because he was so authoritative that whatever he said was believed as if it had been spoken by an angel of the Lord. Some even thought he was naturally an angel who had descended from heaven in human form to remind the people, who had recently returned from captivity.
chunks.original_latin:
IN MALACHIAM PROPHETAM. Malachiam prophetam ultimum duodecim prophetarum,
Hebraei putant esse Esdram prophetam
et sacerdotem. Hic prophetavit eodem tempore quo
et Aggaeus et Zacharias. Unde nec tempus ponitur
in titulo. Interpretatur angelus Domini, sive angelus
meus, quia tantae fuit auctoritatis, ut quidquid dixisset,
ita crederetur velut ab angelo Domini dictum
fuisset. Unde nonnulli putaverunt eum natura angelum
de coelo descendisse carne indutum, ad commonefaciendum
populum, qui nuper de captivitate
reversus erat.
